description:
Synchytrium endobioticum is a fungus-like microorganism that belongs to the phylum Chytridiomycota. It is the causative agent of the disease known as potato wart or black scab, which affects potato plants.

Synchytrium endobioticum is an obligate biotrophic parasite, meaning it can only survive and reproduce within the living cells of its host plant. The fungus-like organism infects the meristematic tissues of the potato plant, primarily the tubers and sprouts, leading to the formation of unsightly wart-like growths on the affected tissues.

The life cycle of Synchytrium endobioticum involves the production of resting spores, known as sporangia, which can persist in the soil for several years. When conditions are favorable, these sporangia release motile zoospores that can infect the host plant's cells. Once inside the plant cells, the zoospores develop into sporangia, which eventually rupture and release more zoospores, perpetuating the infection cycle.

Synchytrium endobioticum is considered a significant threat to potato production, as it can lead to substantial yield losses and the contamination of agricultural soils. The disease is classified as a quarantine pest in many countries, and strict measures are taken to prevent its spread and introduction into new areas.
